title: n8n & AI: Event-Driven Customer Support System
description: An event-driven n8n automation system that classifies incoming customer messages, retrieves contextual knowledge using vector search, and generates consistent, automated responses.
longDescription:
Context
Handling customer communication at scale is not a tooling problem — it is a
decision problem. Incoming messages vary in intent, urgency, relevance, and
required context, yet most systems rely on either manual handling or rigid,
rule-based automation.

This results in wasted effort, inconsistent responses, and poor reuse of
organizational knowledge.

What I Built
I designed an event-driven AI support intelligence system using n8n that treats every
incoming message as a decision to be evaluated, not a ticket to be processed.

The system listens to live communication channels (email and chat), determines
whether a message actually requires attention, retrieves the right internal
context when needed, and generates structured responses using an AI agent —
without hard-coded rules or static workflows.

How the System Works in Practice
When a message arrives:
- It is first classified to understand intent and relevance
- Non-actionable or low-signal messages are filtered out early
- Relevant queries trigger contextual retrieval from internal documents
- An AI agent reasons over both the message and retrieved context
- The final response is generated and sent automatically, with memory retained
  for future interactions

Each step exists to reduce unnecessary AI calls, control behavior, and keep the
system predictable rather than “chatty”.

Design Decisions That Matter
This system was intentionally designed around control and clarity:
- Classification is used to avoid blindly responding to everything
- Vector retrieval replaces brittle rule-based logic
- AI is treated as a reasoning layer, not a decision-maker
- Routing logic is explicit, not hidden inside prompts
- Components are modular to allow reuse across other workflows

The result is a system that behaves consistently, scales cleanly, and remains
auditable.

Why This Is Useful Beyond Support
While implemented in a customer support context, the same architecture applies
to:
- Internal operations queries
- Research and document-heavy workflows
- Finance and reporting support systems
- Consulting-style analysis pipelines
- Any environment where inputs must be evaluated before action

This project demonstrates how AI can be embedded into real decision workflows
without turning the system into a black box.
category: n8n Automation, AI Agents, Decision Intelligence

title: AI-Driven Invoice Processing & Reconciliation System
description: An AI-driven system that ingests invoices, extracts structured financial data, validates records, and automates reconciliation workflows to reduce manual finance operations effort.
longDescription:
Context
Invoice handling in most organizations is still a manual, error-prone process.
Documents arrive in multiple formats, data must be extracted and validated,
and reconciliation often depends on human checks across spreadsheets and systems.

This creates delays, inconsistencies, and operational risk — especially as
invoice volume scales.

What I Built
I designed an AI-driven invoice processing system that treats invoices as
structured financial inputs rather than static documents.

The system ingests invoice files automatically, extracts relevant financial
fields, validates the data, and appends clean, structured records into a
centralized ledger for downstream processing and review.

How the System Works in Practice
When new invoice files are detected:
- Files are discovered and downloaded automatically
- Each document is analyzed and parsed using AI-based extraction
- Key fields such as invoice number, vendor, amount, and dates are identified
- Extracted data is normalized and validated through custom logic
- Clean records are appended into a structured finance sheet
- The system loops continuously to handle multiple invoices without manual input

The workflow is designed to minimize human intervention while maintaining
control over data quality.

Design Decisions That Matter
This system prioritizes reliability over novelty:
- Explicit looping and validation to prevent partial ingestion
- AI used for extraction, not blind automation
- Custom logic layers to enforce consistency before storage
- Separation between document analysis and financial record creation

The goal is predictable, auditable finance operations — not black-box automation.

Why This Is Useful Beyond Invoices
While implemented for invoice workflows, the same architecture applies to:
- Expense processing
- Financial document normalization
- Ops and compliance reporting
- Back-office automation in finance teams

This project demonstrates how AI can be embedded into finance operations
without sacrificing control or traceability.

title: Zomato Strategic & Valuation Analysis
description: A consulting-style strategic and valuation analysis of Zomato, combining discounted cash flow valuation, competitive benchmarking, and scenario-based strategic recommendations.
longDescription:
Context
High-growth consumer internet companies often trade at significant premiums
to intrinsic value, driven by future optionality rather than current cash
flows. Understanding whether these premiums are justified requires combining
rigorous valuation with strategic analysis.

This project analyzes Zomato as a listed Indian consumer-tech company operating
across food delivery and quick commerce, with a specific focus on Blinkit-led
growth expectations.

What I Did
I conducted a full investment-banking-style valuation and a consulting-style
strategic assessment to evaluate whether Zomato’s market pricing is supported
by fundamentals and strategy.

The analysis integrates financial modeling, market sizing, competitive
benchmarking, and scenario-based strategic reasoning.

Valuation & Financial Analysis
- Built a bottom-up DCF valuation with explicit revenue, margin, and cash flow
  assumptions
- Performed common-size P&L analysis and benchmarking against key competitors
- Evaluated capital efficiency and profitability trends post scale-up

Key valuation output:
- Enterprise Value (DCF): ₹72,035 Cr
- Equity Value: ₹66,376 Cr (WACC 10%, terminal growth 5%)
- Market capitalization at analysis: ~₹2.9 Lakh Cr

The valuation gap indicates the market is pricing in strong long-term optionality,
primarily driven by Blinkit and adjacent growth opportunities.

Strategic Analysis
The strategic assessment focused on:
- Market sizing for Indian food delivery and quick commerce
- Unit economics and scalability of Blinkit
- Competitive positioning and execution risk
- Sustainability of current profitability trends

Three strategic scenarios were evaluated:
- Aggressive growth prioritization
- Profitability-first optimization
- Balanced growth with disciplined capital allocation

Key Conclusion
While Zomato’s current market valuation exceeds intrinsic value based on
conservative cash flow assumptions, a balanced growth strategy provides the
most sustainable path forward — preserving profitability while selectively
investing in high-return growth segments.

Why This Project Matters
This project demonstrates the ability to:
- Translate financial models into strategic insight
- Combine valuation rigor with consulting frameworks
- Evaluate market expectations versus fundamentals
- Communicate complex analysis in a decision-oriented narrative

The approach mirrors how investment banks and consulting firms assess
high-growth public companies.

title: Transaction Fraud Detection & Risk Scoring System
description: A machine-learning–driven system that analyzes transactional data, identifies anomalous patterns, and flags high-risk transactions through a live, interactive decision interface.
longDescription:
Context
Fraud detection is fundamentally a risk assessment problem, not just a
classification task. Financial transactions exhibit complex patterns where
false positives increase operational cost and false negatives expose the
system to direct losses.

Effective fraud systems must balance accuracy, interpretability, and
real-time usability.

What I Built
I designed an end-to-end fraud detection system that transforms raw
transaction data into actionable risk signals through a structured
machine learning pipeline and a live decision interface.

The system separates model development from deployment, enabling scalable
and repeatable fraud analysis without retraining overhead.

How the System Works in Practice
The workflow follows a production-oriented pipeline:
- Transaction data is cleaned, preprocessed, and feature-scaled
- A supervised machine learning model is trained to identify anomalous
  transaction behavior
- The trained model is serialized using joblib for efficient reuse
- A live web interface allows users to submit transactions for analysis
- Each transaction is evaluated in real time and flagged based on risk
  probability rather than binary outcomes

This design allows stakeholders to interpret results as decision support,
not absolute truth.

Design Decisions That Matter
Key choices were made to reflect real-world constraints:
- Separation of training and inference to ensure system stability
- Model persistence to avoid unnecessary retraining
- Focus on risk scoring instead of hard yes/no decisions
- Lightweight deployment to support fast iteration and usability

The emphasis was on building a reliable decision layer rather than optimizing
for leaderboard-style metrics.

Why This Matters Beyond Fraud
The same architecture generalizes to:
- Credit risk assessment
- Transaction monitoring systems
- Compliance and anomaly detection
- Operational risk analytics

This project demonstrates how machine learning can be embedded into
risk-sensitive financial workflows without turning the system into a
black box.
category: Machine Learning, Risk Analytics, Financial Systems

title: Banking Transactions & Customer Analytics Dashboard
description: An interactive Power BI dashboard designed to analyze banking transactions and customer behavior across geographies, enabling data-driven insights for revenue, customer segmentation, and payment trends.
longDescription:
Context
Banks and financial institutions generate large volumes of transactional data,
but decision-making often relies on static reports or fragmented views of
customer activity.

To be useful, analytics dashboards must go beyond visualization and enable
clear interpretation of revenue drivers, customer behavior, and geographic
patterns.

What I Built
I developed an interactive Power BI dashboard that consolidates banking
transaction and customer data into a single analytical view.

The dashboard is designed to help stakeholders quickly understand how revenue,
customer segments, and transaction behavior vary across regions, categories,
and payment methods.

What the Dashboard Enables
The dashboard provides:
- Revenue and transaction-level performance metrics
- Active customer tracking and average transaction value
- Geographic analysis across key global markets
- Customer segmentation by demographics and behavior
- Category and subcategory-level transaction breakdown
- Payment method analysis across different transaction types

Interactive filters allow users to dynamically explore trends by year,
category, and subcategory without rebuilding reports.

Design Decisions That Matter
The focus was on clarity and usability:
- KPIs prioritized at the top for immediate visibility
- Geographic and segment-level views to identify concentration risk
- Filters designed to support exploratory analysis, not static reporting
- Visual hierarchy optimized for executive-level consumption

The dashboard emphasizes interpretability over visual complexity.

Why This Matters
This project demonstrates the ability to translate raw transactional data into
decision-support analytics for financial services use cases.

The same approach applies to:
- Retail banking analytics
- Customer profitability analysis
- Transaction monitoring and reporting
- Business performance dashboards for finance teams

It highlights how structured analytics can support informed decisions without
requiring advanced modeling.
category: Data Analytics, Financial Services, Business Intelligence

title: Automated Financial Statement & Ratio Analysis Model (Excel)
description: An automated Excel-based financial analysis model compatible with Screener-style data, combining ratio computation and an integrated dashboard to support structured company evaluation.
longDescription:
Context
Equity analysis often starts with financial data exported from platforms such as
Screener, but raw data alone is not decision-ready. Analysts typically spend
significant time cleaning inputs, recalculating ratios, and building views to
interpret performance trends.

This friction slows down screening and introduces inconsistency across analyses.

What I Built
I built an automated Excel-based financial analysis model designed to work with
Screener-compatible financial data formats.

The model ingests standardized financial statements, structures them
automatically, computes key financial ratios, and presents insights through an
integrated Excel dashboard for quick interpretation.

What the Model Enables
The model supports:
- Direct ingestion of Screener-exported financial data
- Automated structuring of income statement, balance sheet, and cash flow data
- Formula-driven computation of profitability, liquidity, and leverage ratios
- Trend analysis across reporting periods
- A dashboard view summarizing key financial metrics and signals
- Rapid identification of strengths, weaknesses, and potential red flags

The emphasis is on speed, consistency, and repeatability of analysis.

Design Decisions That Matter
- Input sheets aligned with Screener’s export structure
- Clear separation between raw inputs, calculations, and dashboard outputs
- Automation through formulas rather than manual recalculation
- Ratios and visuals chosen for analytical relevance, not quantity

This design allows the sheet to function as a reusable screening and analysis
tool rather than a one-off spreadsheet.

Why This Matters
This project demonstrates a strong foundation in accounting and financial
analysis, along with the ability to translate raw financial data into structured,
decision-ready insights.

It reflects practical analyst workflows and serves as a base layer for more
advanced automation and AI-driven financial systems.
